description: From Middle English dispelen, from Latin dispellere (“to disperse; to dispel”).

entries.meaning: An act or instance of dispelling.
examples: “My dispel didn't work,” she said finally. “He wasn't a blood witch, Sunny,” I said.

verbs.description: dispel (third-person singular simple present dispels, present participle dispelling, simple past and past participle dispelled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To drive away or cause to vanish by scattering.
(transitive) To remove (fears, doubts, objections etc.) by proving them unjustified.
